titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxiv — no.35 Richmond, Va. Tuesday morning, February 10, 1863. price one Cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at six and A Quarter cents Per Week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: Milroy at Winchester.
div3.p:
A letter written from the neighborhood of Winchester, on the 25th of last month, represents Milroy to be a "second Beast Butler" In his treatment of the inhabitants of that unfortunate town.
The flooring, doors, windows — in short, all the wood-work of unoccupied buildings, has been carried off and burned, or otherwise used for the purposes of the Yankee camp, and the beautiful church edifices of the town are being despoiled and stripped in the same way, as well as those in the neighboring village of Kernstown.
Their ravages have also extended to the country houses, the floors and sleepers of which have been torn up and carried off, and the stables and out houses of a number of citizens have been wholly destroyed.
Those of the negro population who had remained faithful during the former occupation of the town by the Yankees, are either being seduced or coerced from the service of their owners, and carried off. Whilst these scenes are being enacted there, Gen. Jones, with his command, is quietly reposing in their comfortable quarters some fifty miles higher up the Valley.

Few towns in the Confederacy have suffered more since the commencement of the war than Winchester.
Its inhabitants have lost all save their honor, which they have preserved, and will preserve, untarnished amid the fires of persecution to which they are subjected.

Not are the true and loyal people of the neighboring county suffering less severely than those of Winchester.
Not only are their horses, cattle, and provisions being violently seized and taken from them, but the barns and stables of the farmers — some of them large and expensive wooden structures — are being torn down and carried to the enemy's camp at Winchester, where they are being used as fuel, or in building huts for the accommodation of their men Gentlemen in the country are being arrested upon the slightest and most trivial pretexts, taken to the town, and after being confined for two or three days in loathsome guardhouses are condescendingly permitted to return to their homes, but invariably with the loss of their horses.

div3.head: Desertions from the Yankee army.
div3.p:
The demoralization in the Yankee army appears to be wide spread and increasing.
A day or two ago the telegraph told the story of its ravages in Banks's command, and from ladies who arrived in this city by the Central train yesterday evening, from Loudoun county, we learn that scarcely a day passes without witnessing scenes of "fighting Joe's" chivalric warriors, wending their way homeward.
About ten days ago several hundred of them, armed, crossed the Potomac, avowing their determination to do so if it had to be accomplished with powder and ball.
However much the Yankees may have seemed disposed to fight for the negro, they don't seem to relish the odor of fighting with him.

We also learn that in Washington city, caricatures are posted in numerous public places, representing a greased pole, with Richmond at the top and Burnside endeavoring to climb it, with the assistance of Seward, Stanton, and old Abe, who are vigorously pushing, but with each new effort falling back.
The people of that city are also represented as being much bolder in their denunciations of the Administration and the war than ever before.
The odiferous nigger is having his effect; the Lincoln regime is smelling bad in the nostrils of the people.

div3.head: Stonewall Jackson's Popularity.
div3.p: A few days since a lady who came through the lines at Fredericksburg under flag of truce, brought a message from Hon. D. W. Voorhees, of Indiana, to Gen. Jackson, to the effect that he (Stonewall) was the only man living who could beat him (Voorhees) in his Congressional district, so great is the admiration of the distinguished chieftain in the Northwest.

div3.head: Destruction by the enemy.
div3.p:
--Col. Blue, who is now the Superintendent of the Penitentiary, in having his household good removed from Hampshire to Staunton had his wagons and horses captured on their return to Hampshire, on North river, in Hampshire county, and his wagons burned and horses taken by the Yankees. One of the teams belonged to William Hook, a neighbor of Colonel Blue, who had taken a load of goods to Staunton for the Colonel, and who had purchased $1,300 worth of tobacco to sell to his neighbors on his return.
The tobacco and wagons (three in number) were burned, and the horses (eleven or twelve in number) taken off by the Yankees--six of Colonel Blue's, four of Mr. Hook's, and two of Charles Carlyle's, who was aiding Col. Blue in removing.
Two of the wagons belonged to Col. Blue and one to Mr. Hook.
They were good, new wagons, and excellent horses.

div3.head: Alleged spy arrested
div3.p:
--Detective Franklin, of the Provost Marshal's office, arrested a person named Wm. Hook, a workman at Pham's foundry, Cary street, on the charge of being a spy. Hook came originally from Norfolk.
It is alleged that he has betrayed several loyal men into the hands of Yankees, and made in the last few months one or more trips to Norfolk, where he communicated with the public enemy.
The truth or falsity of these allegations will be made known on a future examination, to abide which defendant was sent to prison.

div3.head: Shocking.
div3.p:
--On yesterday morning on Broad st., between 9 and 10 o'clock, a most shocking and revolting sight was witnested.
A stalwart negro, bareheaded and barefooted walking in the middle of the street broken out in the worst form of small-pox, under the guard, apparently, of a trooper.
In the name of common decency and humanity let this not occur again.

div3.head: Fire.
div3.p:
--The alarm of fire yesterday morning, at 8 o'clock, was caused by the burning of two small wooden houses on the south side of the dock, on a line with 17th street, which caught fire accidentally.
The houses were occupied by Maurice O'Callahan and Patrick Brady, who saved most of their furniture.

div3.head: Flag of truce.
div3.p:
--About three hundred Abolition soldiers were sent to City Point yesterday by flag of truce, in charge of Lieut. Boseleux.
All of the prisoners taken by Gen. Bragg at Murfreesboro', and sent to the Libby prison, have been forwarded to the North.

div3.head: Court proceedings.
div3.p: --John, slave of Jos. Brigham, arrested by the watch with a lot of sugar and a silver watch, which it was supposed he had stoled, was examined and acquitted.

Albert W. Sinclair, otherwise called Litford, was arraigned for forgery.
It was charged that the defendant had forged the name of Mrs. Fanny Mathias to a certificate authorizing the Clerk of the Hustings Court to issue a license to marry her daughter, which license was by that means procured, and the marriage duly celebrated.
The evidence sustained the charge and the Mayor sent the prisoner on to answer the charge before the Hustings Court.
The defendant had previously been sent on to the same tribunal for stealing a horse from John J. Osborn and a coat from Wm. B. Biglow.
Jim Roberts, free negro, having used abusive and insulting language to Frank Callahan, was ordered 25 lashes.
The case against Wm. R. Warden for getting two hogsheads of sugar from Richard Cauthorn by false pretenses, was continued for further examination.
Washington, slave of Wm. H. Brock, was ordered 30 lashes for carelessly driving a wagon over a son of Mr. Thos. Butler.
Wm. D. Wade, a soldier, charged with getting drunk and throwing stones in the lot occupied by Mr. R. T. Seal, police officer, was sent before the Provost Marshal.

Sundry darkles were arraigned for petty offences.
Marshall, slave of Henry Yarbrough, pass out of date, discharged.
Laden, slave of Fredericksburg Railroad company, no pass, ordered 10 lashes.
Sam, slave of T. C. Harrold, no pass and having two blankets and two balls of thread in his possession, supposed to have been stolen, and resisting the watchmen, ordered 30 lashes.

Hustings Court, Monday, Feb. 9th-- The regular monthly meeting of the Aldermen's Hustings Court commenced to-day, Recorder Jas. K. Caskie, Senior Alderman Richard D. Sanxey, Joseph Maye, Mayor, and Alderman Bray, presiding.
Edward H. Freeman was nominated and confirmed a deputy of the High Constable.

Eliza Hall was fined $10 and cents, for allowing her slave, Mary, to go at large and hire hers if out, contrary to law. The same fine was imposed on Jno. Raynolds for allowing his slave, Tom, to go at large.

The Grand Jury, George W. Smith acting as foreman, assembled, and, having received their charge, withdrew, and after some time spent in the examination of witnesses returned into Court with presentments against the following parties for misdemeanors, viz: Samuel Stanley.
Frances Mathews Joseph J. Apperson, Joseph Bliss, Margret Raull, Copeland, William R. Warden, Mery Vanderille, Daniel Legan, George W. Nelson, (two catch) and P. S. O'Curry.
The Grand Jury adjourned to race on Friday next, at 12 o'clock, on which day they will dispose of another batch of misdemeanor cases.
The Court adjourned to meet at 11 o'clock to-day.

argument.p: the election — rascality among the Yankee officials — Imprisonment of a Lady — the emancipation proclamation — movement of troops, &c.

div4.head: [Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.]
div4.p: I regret my inability, through the irregularity of the mails, to keep you advised of events as they transpire in our midst, but as our worthy Postmaster General has not yet completed his postal arrangements between your city and this point I must be content to avail myself of such opportunities as chance may throw in my way. I should trespass too much on your columns were I to detail all matters of interest that have occupied the attention of our people since my last, yet I cannot neglect a reference to some few, old they may be, and, perhaps, already known to your readers.

The election held some time since in this and our sister city for a member to represent the district in the Federal Congress, merits notices only from the apparently large vote that was given, and the manner in which the election was conducted, and that any wrong impression in regard to the former may be removed.
Some six or seven hundred votes were polled at this place, when not over two hundred Union voters reside in the city.
The polls were surrounded during the day by Yankee soldiers, and arms were stacked in the commissioner room ready for service at any moment.
Any and all persons were allowed to vote, and every man that could be hunted up from this or any other State was carried up without question and permitted to record his name.
Some few persons were intimidated by the threats held out, and reluctantly went to the polls, but sneaked away as quickly as possible, fearing to be seen in a crowd that would have disgraced the "Five Points" in its palmiest days.
Notwithstanding this trick of a desperate Administration, the people here are as true as steel, and more determined than ever in their hostility to Yankeedom.

A bit of rascality in "high" quarters has leaked out within the last few days.
I wrote you something of one Captain Aaron Seeley, former Provost Marshal of this city.
This individual has been detected in a game for filling his empty pockets, which in other times would have been called stealing — Negroes in leaving their masters frequently bring with them horses and mules, and these were turned over to Capt. Seeley, who, in time, transferred them to one Marshall Hutchinson, jailor now, as he was under the Confederates, who would dispose of them to the best advantage and divide the proceeds.
Applications for the recovery of this stolen property developed the villainy of Seeley and his man Friday, and the former was threatened with prosecution by Gen. Viels.
Seeley could not submit to exposure, and very complacently informed the Governor that the execution of this threat would ensure a peep into his own little private transactions.
Captain Seeley was, of course, allowed to resign.
This is not the only branch of the business carried on by this gallant officer, for he has been detected in transferring liquors from the Quartermaster's Department to Hutchinson, and was fairly caught in having forged Gen. Veile's name to a pass, whereby some $25,000 worth of goods were en route for your city.
A very pretty speculation this would have been for a Yankee Captain.
The truth is, that Federal officials in this department are coming money by a shameful system of swindling, and a staunch Union merchant of this city — W. S. Lemosey — recently declared that he was in possession of information sufficient to convict both Dix and Veile of the grossest dishonesty.
The truth of this charge will appear when I tell you that only a select few are permitted the privilege of bringing goods to this market from the North, while many "loyal" men are refused.
Who receives the benefit of this monopoly?
The question is not difficult to answer.

Confederate and Virginia Treasury notes are prohibited from circulating by an order from the Military Governor.
This bears very hard upon the poor soldiers' wives, who are receiving all remittances in the latter.
Purchasers are already in the market, and swindling will be going on briskly.--This is but another scheme adopted by this corrupt department to cheat the people and replenish their own pockets.

Mrs. Mercer, wife of Dr. Mercer, an amiable and accomplished lady of this city, was imprisoned in the county jail, in a felon's cell, with nothing for her comfort but the cold and cheerless walls, during one of the severest nights we have had this winter.
The "head and front of her offending" was in telling the Provost Marshal, after a vain appeal in behalf of her son, a frail and defeate youth, incarcerated for some trivial offence by this same Provost, one Captain York, "that a Southern gentleman would not have refused a mother's appeal"This aroused the ire of this brutal coward, and she was made to experience the joys of a gloomy and desolate dungeon.
These Yankees are wonderful specimens of a gallant people.

Rather an unusual stir was visible among the "rank and file" in this place a few days since — officers were moving to and for with great rapidity, and all privates were ordered to appear at their quarters in fifteen minutes with thirty rounds of cartridges.
Gunboats were drawn up in line of battle, and their guns brought to bear on the city.
This preparation was occasioned by a report carried to "Headquarters that the "rebels" were on this side of Suffolk, and would be is in the course of the night.
The cowardly devils were frightened out of their wits, and it was increased by a terrible fire which broke cut in the night, threatening at one time to destroy a large portion of the city.
The fire was a "secesh" signal, and produced not a little consternation among these rascals.
Of course, there was no truth in the report.

The emancipation proclamation of Lincoln, or rather, I should say, the exceptions in that proclamation is but another evidence of the damnable perfidy of this damnable Administration.
Though protending that slaves are to remain in their proper condition, or as if no proclamation had been issued, they are every day discharged from the service of their owners by military authority, and the protection of the Government given to them when required.
Not an instance to the contrary has yet transpired.

May I not appeal to you to say a word in behalf of the destitute and starving poor in this community?
I mentioned the subject in my first letter, and I feel myself again called upon to advert to it. Congress is now in session and if it has the power surely it will not hesitate to exercise it for he relief of those who are left without protection or support by the action of the Government.
Wives, mothers, children, and sisters, have yielded up cheerfully to the service of their country those upon whom they have relied for bread.
In their privations and sufferings no word of complaint escapes them; they bear it all with a fortitude that would do honor to the first hero on the field of battle.
Love for their native land makes them patient in the midst of starvation, and with stout hearts they hope on and look forward to a better day. But they cannot starvs, and if the Government will do nothing for them, their last appeal will be to their enemies. Shall this be done?
In the name of justice, honor, humanity, duty, never!

Incendiaries are rampant in the community, and but few nights pass without an alarm of fire.
The destruction of property has been great, and promises to be greater.

The Monitor No. 2 is now at the Navy-Yard with a broken shaft.
She was towed up on Friday.

Much discontent exists among the soldiery in and about here, and desertions, it is said, are constantly occurring.
The men have not been paid off for months, and without a cent of money many of the poor wretches are going through the market daily, offering for sale their coats, pantaloons, shoes, sugar, soap, or whatever else they pick up. Not a few of the officers are heartily disgusted with the service and wish themselves clearly cut of it.

Wm. Wheeler, a Virginian, Chief Engineer in the Federal Navy, forwarded his resignation to the proper head, but not being a lowed to resign, his name was stricked off. I understand that he reports one hundred and eight other resignations.
Cause assigned — Lincoln's Proclamation.
Rather late in the day.

The order regarding license, of which I wrote you, has been executed, and none but "loyal" persons are now doing business; some few merchants only bowed to the tyrant's decree and swallowed the oath, the remainder rejected it with scorn.

The transportation of troops in this direction has altogether ceased for the present, and all is now comparatively quiet.
The railroad is, however, being thoroughly repaired, and another heavy locomotive reached hers from the North a few days since.
More cars have also arrived.
I have written in great haste, as but a short time was given before the "departure of the mail."
S.
[Wing has been refused a seat in the Yankee Congress on account of the smallness of the vote cast]

div3.head: Raising of the blockade at Sabine pass.
div3.p: We find the following in the Houston Telegraph, dated Sabine Pass, January 4th:

The "terrible gunboat Dan," the flag ship of the squadron composing the blockading fleet off Sabine, is no more.
At 5 o'clock a party of ten men, composed of Sergeant Conner, privates Spencer, Straim Berwick, Davis. Richardson, Crider, Bolin, and Radleff, boarded her under the guns of the fleet, removed what was of value, and set fire to her. The fleet supposed that the grand army of the Nesches and gunboat flotilla was upon them, and so they hoisted sail and skedaddled, leaving the Dan to her fats.

div3.head: The shoe manufacturers.
div3.p:
--Gov. Vance, of North Carolina, has commenced investigating the conduct of the shoe manufacturers of the State, and in every case where the provisions of the exemption law have been disregarded the offenders having failed in confine their profits to seventy-five to has caused the employers and all their work to be completed.
Three of the establishments in the States have been in consequence of his proceedings, and all hands sent to camps of instruction.
The result is a great decline in the price of leather, when manufactured, throughout the State.
These things will bear a little looking into in other States.

div4.head: The blockade at Charleston.
div4.p:
The Yankee papers, of the 5th and 6th, are reproducing the authorities on international affairs about the blockade which have already been quoted by the Southern papers.
The New York Times, of the 6th, closes an article as follows:

q.p: Some of our neighbors are expending a great deal of industry and some little learning in discussing the question whether the rebel ram Palmetto State has actually broken the Charleston blockade or not. The enormous exaggerations of the rebel newspapers, in stating the facts of the case, leave very little solid ground for argument upon the subject; and the official dispatches, though couched in the most extravagant language, throw an air of ridicule over the pretensions which they themselves have put forward in connection with it.

div4.p:
All that they have actually done is to compel the surrender of one vessel, and "disperse" the rest so that they could not be seen in a dense fog. If, during this temporary opening of the gate, any foreign vessel had entered the harbor, they would have been protected in so doing, and to that extent the blockade would have been raised.
But, so far as appears, no attemp of the kind was made.
And before night our blockading vessels were again in position.

We beg to suggest to the Government that the shortest way of ending all these controversies about the blockade would be to take Charleston. We have iron clads enough unemployed to do it, and plenty of officers who would gladly undertake it. This and a few other Southern sorts once in our possession, we should have no further trouble in maintaining the efficiency of the blockade.
It also has the following dispatch from Washington:

q.p:
The reports in regard to the encounter off Charleston harbor being from rebel sources are doubtless greatly exaggerated.
There has been no intervention of the blockade, and no such assumption will be admitted by the Government.

div4.p: A telegram was received to-day from Fortress Monroe, saying:

q.p: Gen. Dix is in receipt of rebel news from Charleston to the 3d instant, at which time that port was thoroughly blockaded the Federal iron clads lying inside of the wooden vessels.

div4.p: The former were not with the fleet at the time of the attack on the 1st inst.
An attack on the city was momentarily expected.
A dispatch boat, with an official account from Admiral Dupent is hourly expected.

There is reason to believe that the plans of the Davy Department did not contemplate the beginning of the attack by our iron clads on Charleston or Savannah for nearly a fortnight yet; but it is surmised in more than one well informed quarter that the recent daring operations of the rebels at Charleston will be followed by a swifter retribution than they expected and the proclamation that the blockade of Charleston was raised proved truer than they thought.

div4.head: The canal at Vicksburg.
div4.p: The latest Yankee account from the canal across the point near Vicksburg says that 1,000 negroes have been ordered from Memphis to work on it. It adds:

q.p:
The high water of the river at the pretent time has demonstrated most fully the impracticability of the canal dug last summer for the purpose of turning the course of the river so as to leave Vicksburg several miles-island.
The canal is apparently a failure.
Water is now running through it, it is true, but so does water run across many of the long points in this curious river during times of freshet.
But this does not change the course of the river.
The main channel still follows the old bed around by Vicksburg, and the most that can now he expected is that the small quantity of water finding its way through the canal will form that course into what is technically called a share — that is, a narrow stream running behind an island, and sometimes navigable in high water.

div4.head: Yankee finances.
div4.p: Mr. Spaulding, (Republican,) of New York, in the course of a speech delivered by him in the House of Representatives, upon the financial condition of the North, said:

q.p:
The time has arrived when our finances must engage the earnest attention of all loyal representatives.
We were in great peril last year; but our dangers are two fold what they were then.
It was very difficult last year to provide the money to meet the large appropriations made for the support of the army and navy.
It will be still more difficult to meet the enlarged requirements of the current and the next fiscal year.

div4.p: The army bill alone appropriates over $731,000,000, which, added to the estimates of all the other expenditures for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1864, amount to the enormous sum of $1,095,431,483,55; to which must be added the amount still required for appropriations and deficiency of the year ending June 30, 1863, and which, according to the report of the Secretary, amounted on the 1st of December, to the sum of $551,221,131.59--making the whole aggregate required to meet appropriations during the next eighteen months $1,743,634,315.15.

div4.head: The Attacks on Fort Donelson and Island no.10.
div4.p: A dispatch from Cairo dated the 4th inst., says there is no further news from Island No.10, but it is supposed that the rebels have been completely driven off.

Cairo, Thursday, Feb. 5.--A dispatch from Fort Donelson to-night says that the fight lasted from 1 to 8 o'clock in the evening, when the rebels retired southward in great disorder.
Their killed is estimated at 200, and wounded at 500.
Our loss was two killed, and 41 wounded and missing.
Nashville, Tenn., Wednesday, Feb. 4. --About five thousand cavalry, under Wheeler, Steams, and Wharton, attacked our force at Fort Donelson yesterday, and were repulsed and utterly routed.

Gen. Mitchell selects the quarters of prominent Secessionists for wounded rebels.
Forty-five are thus quartered.
Gen. Jeff. G. Davis's division, with a cavalry brigade, occupy Franklin.

div4.head: Miscellaneous.
div4.p:
A late letter from Newbern states that an important discovery was made there a few days since.
About a mile and a half from the city, and beyond a dense wood, it was ascertained by accident that the rebels had actually commenced the erection of extensive earthworks, with a view of shelling the place after the departure of the expedition for Charleston.
Precautionary measures were at once taken to prevent the completion of the undertaking.
The Herald of the 5th says: "In the Senate, on the 4th, resolutions looking to a war with France were tabled by a vote of 36 to 9."
A bill has passed both Houses of Congress to allow Kentucky to organize 20,000 Home Guards.
Lincoln on hearing of Governor Morgan's election, telegraphed at once for Thurlow Weed to come to Washington.

div3.head: The condition of the Federal troops at Baton Rouge.
div3.p: --The Port Hudson (La.) Courter, of the 24th ult., has the following about the Federal army at Baton Rouge:

q.p:
We conversed yesterday with a staff officer who had just returned from Baton Rouge, having gone there with a flag of truce.
He fully corroborates the fact that entire regiments of Federal troops have lain down their arms and peremptorily refused to do duty.
They are heartily sick of the war and its prime movers.
So long as they were defending the honor of their country's flag they were satisfied, but when Lincoln's emancipation scheme was announced they felt anxious to back out and have done so, regardless of consequences.
Our friend said that every officer with whom he conversed seemed satisfied that subjugation of the South was an utter impossibility.

div3.p:
They were particularly anxious to inquire what course President Davis intended to pursue with regard to officers taken prisoners by the Confederate troops who had formerly served under Boast Butter.
They received by way of reply an assurance that President Davis was fully competent to decide their relative merits, and that he would be sure to carry out his decisions to the letter, whatever they might be. The whole city bore the impress of gloom, and looked as though it were doomed to perish like the "Cities of the Plain." "Infact." said our informant, "it looked like nothing else but indige."

div3.head: The State guaranty of Confederate Bonds.
div3.p:
--The bill on this subject, by which it was proposed to increase the amount of the State endorsement of Confederate Bonds from the proportionate share of South Carolina of the amount of $100,000,000 to that of $500,000,000, has passed three readings in both Houses of the Legislature of that State.
The bill is as follows:

q.p: Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives, now met and sitting in General Assembly, and by the authority of the same. That the Governor for the time being, whenever application for such guarantee shall be made to him by the Government of the Confederate States of America, be, and he is hereby, authorized and directed to endorse the guaranty of the State of South Carolina upon the bonds of the Confederate States of America, to be hereafter issued, according to a plan to be adopted by Congress, to the amount of $34,432,758.62 being the proportionate share of the sum of $500,000,000, according to the representation of South Carolina in the House of Representatives of the Confederate Congress, the representation of the States of Missouri and Kentucky being omitted in the calculation.

div3.head: Shocking accident.
div3.p:
--The body of a man, dressed in the uniform of a Confederate officer, the stripes on the cellar indicating the rank of Second Lieutenant was found on the South-Side Railroad, about one mile from Petersburg, Va., Sunday morning. The remains were horribly mangled, and it is supposed that some two or three trains must have passed over decreased during the night.
He was a man of stout form, and apparently 20 years of age. His shirt was marked "Burry."

div4.p: Senate.--The Senate was called to order at 12 o'clock, by Mr. Huster, of Va., and opened with prayer by Rev. Mr. Seeley, of the Baptist Church.

The bill to take private property for public use, by paying to the owner or owners a just compensation for the same, was reported adversely on by Mr. Hill, of the Judiciary Committee.
It was laid on the table.
The chairman of the Committee on Military Affairs reported adversely on the bill granting furloughs to wounded officers and soldiers.

The joint resolution proposing an exchange with the several States of the bonds of the Confederate States for the bonds of said States, which was referred on the 6th of February to the Committee on Finance, and ordered to be printed, was reported on adversely by said committee.

Mr. Hill, of Ga., by leave, introduced a bill entitled "An act to amend the 40th section of an act to establish the Judicial Courts of the Confederate States of America, approved March 16, 1863." It was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary.

Mr. Haynes, of Tenn., reported a bill founded on the resolution directing the Committee on the Judiciary to inquire into the expediency or necessity of regulating by law the seisure and impressment of private property, real and personal, for the use of the armies of the Confederate States.
A bill to regulate impressments by officers of the army was reported on adversely.

A bill to regulate the taking of private property for public use by military authority, and prescribe the mode of determining what shall be just compensation therefore during the existence of the war, war reported on adversely.

A bill to regulate the taking of private property for the public use, and the assessment of compensation therefore, was read a first and second time, and ordered to be placed on the calendar and printed.

Mr. Wigfall, of Texas, who had the floor, giving away, Mr. Burnwell, of S. C., called up the bill to provide for the further issue of Treasury notes, and for other purposes and from the Committee on that subject reported in favor of certain amendments offered by Mr. Hunter.
On his motion, the said bill and amendments were transferred to the secret calendar, and on like motion, the Senate proceeded to consider them in Executive session.
At 3½ o'clock the Senate was still in secret session.
--House met at 12 o'clock, and was opened with prayer by Rev. Dr. Burrows.

Resolutions Introduced and Referred--By Mr. Clopton: A resolution that the Committee on the Medical Department be directed to inquire into the expediency of establishing one or more hospitals in each State, and of providing for the transportation to such hospitals of the sick and wounded soldiers from such States respectively who may be unfit for service for thirty days. Referred to Committee on Medical Department.

By Mr. Foster, of Ala: A resolution that the Committee on Printing be instructed to have 5,000 additional copies of the Presidents Message, and a similar number of the reports of each of the Executive Departments, printed for the use of the House.
Referred to Committee on Printing.

By the same; A resolution that the Committee on Military Affairs be instructed to report a bill providing for the conscribing and placing in the public service in the field, every white male citizen resident or sojourner whithin the Confederate States, without regard to age, physical disability, trade, profession, or pursuit, whenever it may be satisfactorily ascertained that such citizen, resident or sojourner, has refused to receive Confederate money in payment for any article sold or offered for sale by him; and any such citizen resident or sojourner in the Confederate States, should also be made and held liable to be conscribed and placed in the public service in the field, for selling or attempting to sell any article whatever at an advance of more than — per cent, upon the prices charged two years ago for articles of the same kind and quality, whether the same be used for dress, or consumption, or for any purposes whatever.
On agreeing to this resolution the ayes and noes were called, and resulted as follows — ayes 22, noes 55.

Flogging in the Army.--Mr. Smith, of Ala., presented memorials from members of the 43d regiment of Alabama, with reference to flogging in the army.
This memorial was read by the Clerk, when.
Mr. Miles of S. C., stated that the Committee on Military Affairs had instructed him to report a bill abolishing whipping in the army as a punishment.
Mr. Smith, of Ala, moved that the memorial be laid upon the table, which was agreed to; and he then offered the following bill:

q.p: The Congress of the Confederate States do enact, That from and after the passage of this act it shall not be lawful for any court-martial to cause any soldiers in the service of the Confederate States to be punished by whipping, or the infliction of stripes upon his person; and that all laws and customs contravening the provisions of this act be and the same are hereby repealed.

div4.p: Mr. Miles offered as a substitute for this bill the following:

q.p: The Congress of the Confederate States do enact, That the infliction of corpereal punishment by flogging in the armies of the Confederate States is hereby abolished.

div4.p: The vote being taken upon this substitute, it was rejected, and the question recurted upon the original bill, when it was ordered to be engrossed, read a third time, and passed.

Bills for Reference--By Mr. Boteler, of Va.: A bill authorizing the purchase of certain property for the use of the Ordnance Department.
Referred to Committee on Ordnance and Ordnance Stores.

By Mr. Dargan, of Ala: A bill to punish deserters in certain cases.
Referred to Committee on Military Affairs.

By the same, a bill to amend the several acts in relation to Chaplains in the Army.
Referred.
Secret Session--Mr. Foote, of Tenn., then moved to go into secret session, upon which the ayes and noes were called, and resulted — ayes 26, noes 54.

The Exemption Bill--The Exemption bill was then taken up, and the Chair announced that the question was upon the motion of the gentleman from Alabama (Mr. Dargan) to recommit the bill and all its amendments to the Committee on Military Affairs.

Mr. Miles, of S. C., opposed the motion to recommit.
In the present stage of the bill, to recommit it to the Military Committee would afford no information as to the wishes of the House, and would rather mystify than make clear its desires upon this question.
Mr. Foote favored the motion to recommit the bill and its amendments to the Military Committee.
Mr. Conrad, of La., followed Mr. Foote in a speech on the general subject of exemption.
At the conclusion of Mr. C.'s remarks the House adjourned.
--The Senate met at 12 o'clock M., and was called to order by the Lieutenant Governor. --Prayer by Rev. Mr. Pettigrew.

Bills Reported.--A bill to increase the salaries of certain Government officers.
A bill to amend the Code in relation to the sale of free negroes.
A bill to transfer the State Line to the Confederate Government.
A bill to amend the 1st, 3d, 4th, and 7th sections of an "Act to provide for the public defence," passed October 3d, 1862, was ordered to be read a third time and engrossed.
A bill to authorize the establishment of public storehouses in the county of Pittsylvania.
House bill incorporating the Rockbridge Insurance Company was passed

Resolutions of Inquiry--By Mr. Garnett, on so amending the Code of Virginia as to make it unlawful to sell horses infected with the glanders or farcy; by Mr. Ball, of so amending the Code of Virginia as to provide that there shall be no forfeiture of compensation to fiduciaries for failure to settle their accounts, where such settlements have been prevented in the counties of this State by the presence of the public enemy, or by reason of the absence of the fiduciary in the public service; by Mr. Robertson, resolutions touching the case of the prisoners captured by the State Line; by Mr. Pate, on refunding a certain sum of money to Reese Browning; by Mr. Coghill, on amending the act entitled "An Act to provide for the more effectual and speedy transportation of freight and travel through the cities of Richmond and Petersburg," by repealing the second proviso therein; by Mr. Witten, on amending the act to convert the branch of the Northwestern Bank of Virginia, at Jeffersonville, into a separate and independent Bank, and to restore to loyal stockholders any interest or right which may have inured to the State under said act, etc.
On motion, at 3½ o'clock P. M., the Senate adjourned.
--The House met at 12 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Mr. Jeter.

Mr. Rutherfoord, from the Committee on Courts, reported a bill amending an act to amend certain sections of the Code, so as to exempt from distress for rent, payable in money, the property of persons in the military service of the State.
Also, bill to stay proceedings on executors, trustees, and other demands, in cases of refusal to receive payment in currency, and to repeal an act entitled "An act to suspend sales and legal proceedings in certain cases, and to repeal an ordinance to provide against the sacrifice of property, and to suspend proceedings in certain cases" Passed April 30th, 1834 by the Convention of Virginia.
Mr. Barboar, from the Committee on Finance, reported a bill providing for increasing the revenue of the Commonwealth, which was laid upon the table and ordered to be printed.

[This bill increases the rate of invation from 60 cents on $100, as at present, to $1 on $100; the tax on licenses and other subjects of indirect taxation are increased in the same ratio, and some new subjects of taxation introduced.

Mr. Mallory, from the Committee on Military Affairs, reported a resolution asking to be discharged from the consideration of a resolution of inquiry exempting from military service one deputy clerk for each county and one deputy sheriff for every twelve thousand inhabitants; also, to repeal an act passed at the last session to provide for the public defence.
Report agreed to.

On motion of Mr. Gilmer, the rules were suspended and the bill "providing for the appointment of general agents and shockeepers for counties and corperations" was taken up and discussed at considerable length, undergoing various erasures and amendments.
At 3 o'clock, however the further consideration of the subject was postponed until 11½ o'clock to-morrow.
On motion of Mr. Jones, the House adjourned.

div3.head: Just Retaliation.
div3.p:
--The Shelbyville (Tenn.) Banner learns, from the best authority, that Gen. Morgan, a few days since, sent a flag of truce to Marfreesboro', to convey ladies who were anxious to see their sons, reported to be mortally wounded and prisoners.
Gen. Rosecrans seized the whole party, charging them to be spies and threatened their execution.
Gen. Bragg, when informed of the facts, replied with spirit and determination to this violation of the rights of war, and ordered twice the number of Federal officers of the highest grade in his custody to be placed in close confinement preparatory to their being condemned, and hung without delay if Gen. Rosecrans shall execute those embraced under the flag of truce.

div3.head: Steamers captured in Red river.
div3.p: --A special to the Advertiser and Register, dated Jackson, yesterday, says:

q.p:
A Government ordnance agent, who escaped, reports that the Yankee gunboat Queen of the West, which passed the Vicksburg batteries, went below and up Red river, capturing the steamer A. W. Taylor, loaded with sugar and molasses, and having thirty Confederate officers on board, nine of whom escaped.
Also, the steamer Moro, with 180,000 pounds of park for Port Hudson, and the steamer Berwicks Bay, with 200 barrels flour and 100 bales cotton.

div3.p:
The Queen of the West mounts 12 rifled guns, and carries a crew of 150 picked men, under Col. Elliott.
She was struck 20 times, but being cotton clad was little injured.
She has returned to Vicksburg without her prises, which are probably recaptured or destroyed.

div3.head: From Kentucky.
div3.p:
--A resolution has been introduced in the Kentucky Legislature in favor of an armistice.
The Louisville Journal, of the 2d, favors the proposition for a conference between the Kentucky Legislature and Northern Legislatures, to see what shall be done.

div3.head: Skirmish in Tennessee.
div3.p: --A special to the Register from McMinnville, 8th, says Col. Martin, of Morgan's brigade, with 100 men, attacked Reynolds's division yesterday, killing and wounding a number of the enemy, and burning a number of wagons loaded with provisions.

div3.head: A Formidable fleet.
div3.p:
--Information has been received here that a Yankee fleet of over 70 vessels was in Port Royal harbor on Saturday last.
The fleet comprised 52 transports, 15 large war steamers, and four or five iron-clads.
Evidently some grand movement is on hand.

div3.head: Arrival of deserters.
div3.p:
--Deserters from the Federal army are constantly arriving within our lines.
Numbers of them have taken the oath of allegiance.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--To go in one of the best companies from this city.
For a reliable man a liberal price will be paid.
A Virginian over 45 preferred.
div3.closer:
Geo. A. Hundley.
182 Broad st. fe 9--5t*

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--A good, reliable man, over 45 years of age, will receive a liberal price for his services.
Apply at Hill's Ambrotype Gallery, 183 Broad st.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--For a suitable man, over 45 years of age, a liberal price will be paid.
Apply at
div3.closer:
J. C. Ellett's
Grocery, cor. 5th and Marshall sts. ja 28--ts

div3.head: Administrator's notice
div3.p:
--Being anxious to settle up the estate of Alson Richards as soon as possible, I request that all persons indebted to it will at once come forward and settle.
All claims against the estate, if properly authenticated, will be paid upon presentation to the undersigned, at Williamson & Co.,'s auction room, on Governor st., one door above Franklin.
We have for private sale a very likely Chambermaid, about 18 years of age. Apply to

div3.head: For Sale
div3.p: --A fine sized and very likely yellow Boy, nineteen or twenty years old. He is very capable, a swift, active waiter, and quite a good cook; would make a capital servant for an officer, Apply at Grady's jail.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 35, page 2.

div3.head: Advice to President Davis.
div3.p:
We have not the pleasure of a personal acquaintance with our President.
We never saw his face, except in the bookstores and print-shops, but once.
That "once" was last summer, when we passed early in the morning by the Presidential mansion, and saw him sitting in the south perch, reading a newspaper, which instinct assured us was the Dispatch, Indeed, our President is a man of taste, and, as such, necessarily reads the Dispatch. As we are not on the list of "constitutional advisers, " and are paid nothing for our advice, which we mean, nevertheless, to give, we take this method of conveying it, confident that it will be read and appreciated, which latter word is much in use just at this time, and means "taken for what it is worth."

To begin, then, President Davis has offended the Old Lady of the London Times, and she scolds furiously.
It was very wrong in President Davis--very naughty indeed,--he ought not to do so. He must make it up with her, and the sooner the better.
As he may have some doubts as to the quomodo, we must explain it to him. The President, seeing that the Yankees, without the slightest provocation, have invaded our country, burned our houses, murdered hundreds of our fellow-citizens in cold blood, ravished our women, stolen our horses, destroyed our crops, incited our negroes to revolt, and cut their masters' throats — having carried on the war in a spirit whose atrocity can find no parallel this side of Mexico — have put the capstone to their barbarity by proclaiming all our negroes free, urging the main body to take up arms against us, and passing a law to enroll 150,000 of them as soldiers, for the purpose of subjugating or exterminating the whole Southern population, without regard to age, sex, or condition.
Our President has issued a retallatory proclamation, and this has brought upon him the thunders of the London Jupiter.
Now, it is certain that the ruler of the typographical Olympus cannot object to retallation per is. No, no. The Times is consistent, and for much less provocation it recommended, six year ago, the utter destruction of the great city of Delhi, and the indiscriminate massacre of all the inhabitants, men, women, and children!
It abouted with joy whenever the tale of some fresh act of bloody vengeance was wafted across the ocean from the distant shores of India.
The Times, we repeat, is consistent, not fickle; it is cosmopolitan, not John Bullish.
It is not to blind to the eternal laws of right and wrong as to believe that what was just retribution in the case of England is bloody cruelty in the case of any other people.
Englishmen, it never maintains, have a charter to commit crimed which has not been granted to other people.
It is it must be, to the modus operandi, to the manner of inflicting punishment, that the Times, objects.

Now comes our advice to the President.
It is to propitiate the ancient dame of Printing House Square by changing the mode of punishment contemplated for the offence of inciting our slaves to revolt.
Instead of turning captured officers over to the courts, let him have all the prisoners — officers men, sulters, quartermasters, stragglers, and camp followers — tied to the months of cannon and blown to "kingdom come," without notice or delay long enough to say over the Lord's Prayer.
The Times will not be merely pleased — it will be delighted; it will be in ecstacies; it will shout aloud; editors, proprietors, printers, pressmen, engineers, newsboys, and devils, will throw up their caps in a perfect delirium of joy?
It was so when the British officers murdered their captives in India, in that novel and approved style.
While a thrill of herror ran the circle of the whole civilized world, the Times was as impervious as a non-conductor of glass to the electric spark when it starts upon its round.
According to everybody else, it was a murder of unexampled barbarity.
According to the Times, it was retribution worthy of British magnanimity, which no other nation but the British would have had the nerve to exact.
Let the President take the hint, and got into the good graces of the Times as soon as it can; for, we repeat once again, the Times is consistent, and will surely applaud in him what it applauded in the magnanimous assassins of India.

Againt Should our army be fortunate enough to capture any number of general officers, let the President give orders that they be all bundled into carriage, and depute some officer — if he can find one who is willing to damn his own soul without the possibility of redemption — to enter the carriage with a brace of Colt's five shooters and shoot the captives through the head.
It will be all the better if they surrendered upon condition of life and good treatment.
Let him be assured that the Times will applaud him to the very scho, which shall applaud again.
It did so when an English officer, after having gotten possession of the Indian flends upon conditions, and put them in a carriage, stepped into it himself and murdered them all, one of them being, at the time, an old man of eighty, and another a boy of fifty.
Nay, the man who perpetrate this deed of blood — a deed, we venture to say, without a parallel in modern history — was extolled as a hero without a rival even in the glorious annals of "magnanimous England." Let President Davis try the experiment if he wishes to be extolled by the Times,; for the Times extolled the perpetrator of the Indian crime, and surely the Times, is a consistant newspaper.

div3.head: Gen. Burnside.
div3.p: It is said that Lincoln would not consent to accept Gen. Burnside's resignation in the army, but observed in his peculiar vernacular, that he had other "fish for him to fry."
A friend suggests that the best use Gen. Burnside can be put to, is to be placed in a glass case and shown around the country as that unprecedented curiosity, a modest Yankee!

div3.head: Type Wanted.
div3.p:
--The proprietors of this paper wish to purchase 1,000 or 1,500 pounds of Nonpareil or Gate Type.
The highest will be paid.

div3.head: To the voters of Virginia.
div3.p: --Fellow-citizens: Having been requested by many of you of become a cadidate for the office of Governor at the regular election in May next, I respectfully announce that I cheerfully yield to such request, and, in the event of may election, will diligently and to the best of my ability perform the duties of the position.

I am sensible of the responsibilities which I announce my willingness to assume.
I am painfully aware of the giant struggle which is in progress, and that it may be my duty to assume such responsibilities without counting the cost to myself.
In such even I shall unhesitatingly do so,only asking the liberal construction of my fellow-citizens for my vindication and defence.

I regret that it will not be in my power to appear among you and address you upon public affiars.
But, having deemed it my duty to to the army, to which, after a confinement of some months, I am about to return, I shall not have hour to spare for any other purpose, I regret this the less, however, as I flatter myself that I am sufficiently well known to you in person, or by reputation, to nable you to exercise the sovereign power of suffruge with all proper intelligence.

With no parties to divide us — with but one great impulse — that which seeks to protect our liberties and establish our independence — we surely can work together with one will to realize this vital consummation.
At any rate, ifelected,I shall seek to deserve your confidence by devoting to the duties of my position all the powers of mind and body which I
Belloving, if true to ourselves, that a gracious Providence will crown our rightcous and glorious efforts with success, I have the honor to be, most respectfully and cordially, your fellow-citizen.

div4.p: On the 4th inst., by Rev. M. Michelbacher, Mr. Mason Lobb, formerly of Wilmington, N. C. to Miss. Kate Fanduward, of Richmond, Va.
Wilmington, N. C., and Danville papers please copy.
On the evening of the 8th instant, by the Rev. Dr. Burrows, at the residence of Mr. Wm. H. Sutherland, Mr. Jas. H. Aeraham, formerly of King William county, and Miss Mollie W. Hawle, of this city.
Religious Herald please copy. *
On Sunday night, after a very painful illness, Maria Angus wife of John L Byerly.
The friends and acquaintances are invited to attend her funeral on Wednesday morning, at 10 o'clock, from her late residence, 27th and Franklin streets. 2t*
On Monday, the 9th inst, of billious fever, Page Bell, son of Jame W and Caroline E Shields, in the 4th year of his age.
The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend his funeral from the residence of his father this (Tuesday) evening, at 3 o'clock. *
on the 8th inst., after a short but painful illness, Mrs. H G Miller, wife of Stephen Miller, aged fifty years one month and twenty six days.
She leaves a devoted husband and six affectionate children to mourn their loss.

lg.l: Dearest mother, thou hast left us,
And thy loss we deeply feel;
But 'tis God who hath bereft us,
He can all our sorrows heel.

div4.p: Lynchburg and Petersburg papers please copy.
At Buena Vists, in Roanoke county, the residence of her grandfather, Mr. George P Tayloe, on the 2d inst, Mary Taylor, eldest child of Wm. W and Mary T Gwathmey, aged 5 years and 6 months. *

div3.head: Wanted — an Old man Wanted.
div3.p:
--Wanted, immediately, an old man, who is willing to devote his whole time to a light business.
Must be quick at figures and able to write an intelligible hand, and come recommended for honesty and steady habits.
Such an one may hear of a situation by applying at Smith's Agency, 12th street, opposite Enquirer office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A few more men for a cavalry company ready to take the field.
Horses and equipments furnished, and the usual bounty given immediately on enlisting.
Apply opposite the St. Charles Hospital, Main street, (sign of the flag.)
div3.closer:
Henry H. Gill,
Lieut and Recruiting Officer. fe 10--3t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--By a young married gentleman, a native of this city, an unfurnished Room and Board for himself and wife, in a private family residing within fifteen minutes walk of the Post-Office.
References given and required.
Address, stating terms, &c., "X, " Box 528, Richmond P. O.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A gentleman teacher of Piano wishes to obtain a Situation in a respectable family in or out the city.
Address "Mr. T. R." at the Monticello Hotel, Broad street, Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--At Camp Lee Hospital, two negro men, for Cooks; also, one to do general Hospital work.
Applicants must apply immediately.
div3.closer:
W J Speed,
Hospital Steward. fe 10--1t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A good Baker.
Apply to
div3.closer:
B. M. Ellit,
Main and 18th street. fe 10--3t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p: --A good Nurse for a child three years old. Apply at Lindan Row, Franklin street, 3d door from 3d

div3.head: Wanted — a Piano.
div3.p:
--We wish to hire by the month a good Piano.
Apply to

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A French lady, from Paris, desires a situation in a family as Teacher of the French language.
Having had long experience she hopes to give satisfaction.
Apply at the American Hotel.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--Over 45 years of age, to serve in the Confederate Army during the war. For a suitable man a liberal price will be paid.
Apply to Mr. Wm. Long, or to Robert Young, at the Cigar Stand in the Ballard Hotel.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--To go in one of the best infantry companies in service.
He must be a man of good character, well recommended, and over 45 years of age. A liberal price paid.
Apply to

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--A liberal price will be paid to a sound and reliable man over 45 years of age to go as a Substitute in Lawton's brigade.
Inquire at No. 111 Main street.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--Any one wishing to Substitute can get a liberal price by applying at the Linwood House, Room 18 from 8 A. M. until 6 o'clock P. M. to-day.
Good references must be given.

div3.head: Substitute Wanted.
div3.p:
--To go into cavalry.
Call at Jas. Moore's, near the Old Market, between 11 and 1 o'clock to-day.
Horse and equipments furnished.

div3.head: Three Substitutes Wanted
div3.p:
--Able-bodied men, over 45, well recommended.
Apply to-day, at room No. 13 Richmond House.

div3.head: Two Substitutes Wanted.
div3.p: --Call at the store of A P & J L Woodson, four doors above 1st street, on Broad, to-day, from 9 to 2 o'clk.

div3.head: Sergial notice — to the of Henrico
div3.p:
--The having been detailed for thirty days for the county of Henrico, hereby announces to its citizens the partial suspension of the conscript act, so as to allow all conscripts in this county to volunteer in companies of their own selection in this division, and thereby receive the usual bounty of $50 awarded to volunteers.
It is earnestly hoped that these inducements will add a large number of men to the ranks of the army.
I call upon the people of this county to assist me in the good work.
Let every man apply his shoulder to the wheel, and by a determined effort to forward the good work, show to the people of the country that the county of Henrico has not forgotten her duty.
I also call upon the citizens of this county to assist me in returning to duty deserters from the army, who are now at home skulking from their duty, while their fellow soldiers are suffering from the cold and exposure of the winter.
To all such I would say, that I will make every endeavor to arrest them, and return them to their respective companies.
To those wishing to volunteer I would say, that I can be found over the store of Selden & Miller, No. 15 Cary street, between the hours of 9 and 3 o'clock, everyday.
div3.closer:
E A Miller,
1st Lieut. com'dg, 59th Virginia reg't, Recruiting Officer. fe 10--eod3t*

div3.head: Last chance for Absentees.
div3.p:
--Pursuant to orders issued by Major General G W Smith, all members of Capt. J. Hatley Norton's company, (D) 18th Battalion Virginia Heavy Artillery, now absent, are notified that they must report to me at once, and no punishment will be inflicted except the forfeiture of pay for the time absent.--Should they not report immediately, they will be considered as deserters and tried by the new court martial now in session in Richmond; and, if found guilty, will be shot whenever apprehended.
I can be found at the Military Hall, over the Old Market, corner of 17th and Main streets, Richmond, Va.
div3.closer:
W T Chelkley,
Lieutenant and Recruiting Officer, Co D, 18th Va. Bat. fe 10--1aw2t*

div3.head: Important to conscripts, stragglers, and deserters.
div3.p:
--In accordance with order No. 39, issued by Major General Geo. W. Smith, we hereupon assume the duties of Recruiting Officers for the county of Henrico, city of Richmond, and vicinity.
To all concerned notice is hereby given that the operation of the Conscript law is partially suspended in this department.
Any person wishing to volunteer will be allowed to select his own company, provided it be in this Department, and will be entitled to the bounty and all other benefits which are provided for by law to volunteers.
Is like manner all conscripts who come forward voluntarily and make application to this office will be enrolled into any company they may select in this command.
It is hoped and believed that the liberal inducements herein tendered to conscripts will meet with a prompt response, and thus aid in securing ample means for the common defence.

By like command we are instructed to arrest all stragglers and deserters from the army.
To those who report voluntarily we are authorized to declare a free and full pardon, with the exception of forfeiture of pay for the time absent.
Those who fall to report will be arrested and confined until they can be forwarded to their companies under guard.
The co-operation of the people in discountenancing straggling and inducing the laggard to return to duty is hereby earnestly invoked.
We can be found at any time between the hours of 10 A. M. and 3 P. M., in the Military Hall, above the Old Market, corner of 17th and Main sts.

div3.head: Attention, Absentees!--your last chance.
div3.p:
--Pursuant to orders from Major-Gen. G W Smith, all Absentees from Capt. H B. Dickinson's company D, 59th Va. reg, are hereby notified to report to camp by 10th February, 1863, and no punishment will be inflicted "except forfeiture of pay" for the time of absence.
Should they not report by the time specified, they will be tried as deserters by the new Court Martial now in session, and if found guilty punished as such when ever apprehended.
div3.closer:
E A Millne,
1st Lieut. Co D 59th Va. Reg. fe 7--3t*

div3.head:
Camp Battery no. 2 Jan. 31, 1863.
last chance for Absentees.
div3.p:
--Pursuant to orders issued by Major-General Smith, all members of Capt. T P Wilkinson's Company (C,) 10th Battalion Va. Heavy Artillery, now absent, are notified that they must report to camp by the 10th of February, 1863, and no punishment will be inflicted "except the forfeiture of pay" for the time absent.
Should they not report by the time specified they will be considered Deserters, and tried by the new Court Martial now in session in Richmond, and if found guilty will be shot whenever apprehended.
div3.closer:
John W Turner,
2d Lt. Commanding Co C. 10th Bat. Va. Heavy Artillery. fe 3--7t*

div3.head:
Camp Battery no 2, January 31, 1863.
last chance for Absentees.
div3.p: --Pursuant to orders issued by Major-General G. W. Smith, all members of Company A, 10th Battalion Virginia Volunteers, Heavy Artillery, now absent, are hereby notified that if they report to camp by the 10th day of February no punishment will be inflicted, except the loss of pay for time absent.--Should they not report by the 10th day of February they will be considered deserters, and tried by the new Military Court now in session in Richmond, and if found guilty, will be shot whenever apprehended.
div3.closer:
J W Barlow,
Capt. Commd'g Co A, 10th Batt. Va. Vols,
Heavy Artillery. fe 2--9t*

div3.head: Ten Dollars reward.
div3.p: --The above reward will be paid for information of the whereabouts of my boy John Pleasant, who ran away on Thursday, the 5th inst. John is about 17 years old, 5 feet 3 or 4 inches high, kinky hair, yellow complexion, and stiff in his right knee.--The boy also wore when he left, a suit of gray clothes and white hat. Information may be left at Mr. Tabb's, under Exchange Hotel.
div3.closer:
Pat Dougherty,
Rocketts Old Field. fe 20--1t*

div3.head: Seventy five Dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Is offered for the apprehension and delivery of my slave William Henry, who disappeard from the fortifications around Richmond about the 10th of December.
Said slave is about 19 years of age, 5 feet high, thick set, thick of speech, gruff in manner of speaking, and generally clears his throat before beginning; has a peculiarly formed head, protuberance on the back of it, and eyes somewhat popped.
The above reward is offered for the apprehansion and delivery of said slave to me in Danville, or lodged in the jail in Richmond so that I get him in possession.

div3.head: Runaway--$5 reward.
div3.p:
--Ran off from the subscriber from Union Hill, on the 2d inst., a black Girl of the name of Zuliam.
She lived last year with Mrs. Petty, on Main street, between 20th and 21st streets.
She is a thick set, stout Girl, round face, aged about 20 years. I will give the above reward on her delivery to me, or to where I can get her.

div3.head: Beautiful Improved farm, near Charlottesville, and twelve or fifteen negroes, for Sale.
div3.p:
--In obedience to a decree of the Circuit Court of Albemarle, pronounced in the chancery suit of "Henderson and wife vs. Crawford and s," the undersigned Commissioners will offer for sale, at public auction, on the premises, on Tuesday the 3d day of March, 1863, (or the next fair day) a beautiful estate, known as Meadow Clerk, containing about 600 acres. This farm lies within a mile of Charlottesville, and less than a mile from the University of Virginia; has an abandance of timber; is smooth and gently undulating, susceptible of a high degree of improvement; has a large creek passing entirely through the place, affording a quantity of fine meadow land, well set in old grass yielding a large quantity of hay; and there is a spring of running water in every field.
There is an excellent dwelling house, and all the necessary out houses, and a fine peach orchard on the place.
It is seldom that so desirable a place, in the immediate vicinity of a large town, is offered for sale.
Will be sold at the same time and place, 12 or 15 likely negroes, Household and Kitchen Furniture a fine Piano, two good Milch Cows, &c.
Terms--Pretty much at the option of the purchaser.

div3.head:
By Williamson & Co., Auct's.
Trustee's Sale of real estate in the town of Fulton at auction.
div3.p: --By virtue of a deed of trust executed by Richard Hobb and his wife Elizabeth A Robb to the subscriber, dated the 3d day of August, 1854, and recorded in the Clerk's office of Henrico County Court, being requested so to do by the parties interested, I will proceed to sell, on Thursday, the 19th day of February, at 4 o'clock P. M. upon the premises, the property conveyed by said deed, viz: Those three lots of Land lying and being in the county of Henrico, in the town of Fulton, near the city of Richmond, and designated on the plat of said town, (a copy of which is on file in the office of the Clerk of Henrico County Court,) as lots Nos 30, 31, and 36, in square No. 10, and bounded as follows, to wit: Lots Nos 30 and 31 being situated at the Northwest intersection of Fulton and Erin streets, frenting together 60 feet on the North side of Orleans street, and running back between parallel lines, 115 feet; and lot No. 36 being likewise situated on the North side of Orleans street, commencing at the distance of 90 feet East of Fulton street, fronting 30 feet on Orleans street, and running back, between parallel lines, 115 feet.
The title is believed to be good, but selling as Trustee, I will convey only such title as is vested in me.
div3.closer:
Terms.--Cash.
T C Burns, Trustee.
Sale conducted by Williamson & Co., Auct'rs. fe 3

div3.p:
Administrator's Sale of 5,000 Cords of Pine Wood, 100,000 feet of Seasoned Lumber, and one Steam Saw Mill.
Will be sold to the highest bidder, on Thursday, the 12th day of February next, at the Saw Mill lately occupied by Rowland & Shriver, dec'd, about three miles from Cabin Point, Surry co., Va., the following property to wit:

1. Horse and Harnces, 2 yoke of Oxen, I Steam Saw Mill and Fixtures, Wagons, Carts, Carrylogs, also, about 100,000 feet of seasoned Lumber, principally inch boards, and from five to seven thousand cords of Pine Wood, 5 Begle's cross out Saws, 1 pair large Patent Balances, 30 bales of Hay, and all the Fixtures, too numerous to
wishing to purchase the wood or lumber, can have every facility for shipping to Richmond or Petersburg by the Norfolk and Petersburg Railroad, which is only a short distance.
Sale to commence at 11 o'clock A. M., when terms will be made known.
